displaytitle: A youth half-kneeling, with both arms extended
creditline: Bequest of Duane E. Wilder, Class of 1951

makers.displaymaker: François Boucher, 1703–1770; born and died Paris, France

texts.textentryhtml:
F. Adama van Scheltema; sale Amsterdam, 11-14 June 1912, lot 34;

Franc Lamy (1855-1910), Paris; sale Paris, 25-26 November, 1912, lot 6;

Mrs Frederick C. Havemeyer collection, New York; sale New York, Sotheby's, 28 November 1962, lot 33;

sale London, Christie's December 13, 1984, lot 22;

Duane Wilder collection;

Bequeathed to the Princeton University Art Museum
texts.remarks: As per Giada Damen, IMLS Drawings 2018-2020

texts.textentryhtml: More than any other artist, François Boucher is identified with the French Rococo style, known for elaborate embellishment and extravagance, and associated with the court and aristocracy. Adept in all media from painting to the design of tapestries and porcelain figures, Boucher was a technically brilliant draftsman who reinvented the genre of the pastoral, a form of idealized landscape art typically populated by rustic figures in silk dress shown in scenes of sentimental or even erotic love. Boucher made drawings such as this one as finished works of art in themselves for a growing market of collectors, and as preparatory studies for paintings or as designs for printmakers.
texts.remarks: The Eclectic Eye: A Tribute to Duane Wilder

displaymaker: François Boucher, 1703–1770; born and died Paris, France
